To correct excessive tip clearance, refer to the

This gap control is becoming essential when it exists combination of excessive eccentric rotation (between static and rotating parts) and resonance vibration of the blades (see §4.3 vibration analysis for detailed discussion of natural frequencies of fan).
Tip clearance and fan efficiency for different fan sizes
ACHE fans can have fixed or adjustable pitch blades.
Adjustable ones can be either manual (cooler stopped) or automatic (
angle modification by actuator while cooler operated).
rom a mechanical point of view,
reliability of automatic adjustable systems is poor and
soon results in a fixed pitch angle
ixed pitch angle fans are preferred
A common problem with ACHE is improper blade pitch angle.
n optimal blade pitch setting will
For a smooth operation of the fan and avoid any air impulses, the blade angle setting for all blades of each
he reference point to measure the pitch angle is different from manufacturer to manufacturer (at 1
of the tip of the blade, at 2/3
hen a fan manufacturer specifies a pitch angle, it is required to indicate the location of the reference point used to control th

As a reminder, supplier shall select a fan in such a way, that at a specified speed, it should be feasible (by blade pitch angle modification) to gain 10% more air flow, taking the corresponding static pressure increase into consideration. This provision is required by API STD 661 to avoid fan stall, which is generally associated with a drastic loss in fan efficiency.
An increase of 10% of the blade pitch angle leads to:
= distance from blade tip to ruler (refer to OEM specifications)

Note that depending on fan type and material, operating speed and OEM specifications, it may be required to set the blades with an additional predefined angle to balance the dynamic deflection of the blades (flexibility under centrifugal effect).
the relationship between blade pitch angle variation and fan performances.
These formulae are valid for blade pitch variations
= Mechanical Power absorbed at fan shaft (expressed in HP’s)

If ever the static pressure variation does not match th
While adjusting the pitch angle, keep in mind the power rating limitation of the fan driver.
Here are the estimated evolutions of motor current and fan static pressure for 2 degrees’ increase of blade angle:
. At fan stall, the boundary layer of air at the leading edge is changed from laminar to turbulent flow.
The effect of a fan in stall is a horsepower increase but the net fan work actually decreases.
coolers affected by an increase in static pressure as a result of external fouling
or blade pitch angle too high.
, it is usually a combination of the three
negative airflow on a large portion of
high blade pitch angle setting (compared to supplier recommended pitch angle)
A simple remedy to cure the problem is to decrease the blade pitch angle
: if the pitch angle decrease does not result in
Note also that fan stall decreases the airflow (therefore cooling capacity or duty) but as well can lead to vibration problems.
Fan in early stage of stall
As blade pitch is increased, air flow may stall and start to reverse.
It may be stated using smoke or filament strips.
Fan in later stage of stall:
an stall encountered at the Flanders Refinery on an A-frame condenser of the steam turbine driving the Cracked Gas Compressor of the FCC.
A decrease of 7° in blade pitch angle generated an increase in airflow of 35% with an absorbed power decrease of 30%. Note that the static pressure remains unchanged.
Another solution to solve the stall problem is to decrease the pitch angle and increase the fan rotation speed (by replacing the existing gearbox). This solution
enables to fully load the driver
(due to the increase in RPM), thereby increasing the airflow.
position inside the fan ring can

When fan drive uses belt(s) and pulley, it is mandatory to regularly control the belt tension. This tension can be either too low (torque is not fully transmitted or belt maybe weak), either in excess (loads at motor shaft end and fan support can lead to misalignment, premature bearing wear or failure, motor damage and increased maintenance costs): both situations are not acceptable and a wrong belt tension directly impacts the complete transmission life span.
Belt tension can be deducted from a
, but this reading is not easy (access) and not accurate.

are widely used in the industry: based on the harmonic vibration of the stressed belt, the probe reads the existing tension provided that belt material, width and span length are known. This reading is done while fan is shutdown and is based on the natural frequency of the belt.

Specific survey can be conducted cell-to-cell using anemometer to measure the average speed profile of the airflow from hub to tip @ constant speed: this profile will help to identify, understand and correct fan performance troubles.

The determination of the Airflow profile shall be based on an averaged value, based on radial spaced measurements at 90°. The measurements can be conducted on a 5-rings map (see hereafter example) or 10-rings map.
5-rings map includes 5 readings per radius, so 10 readings for diameter and 20 total readings.
10-rings map means 10 readings per radius, so 20 readings for diameter and 40 total readings.
Here are the locations of measuring points for a 10-rings map:
High resolution Thermal Camera (FLIR, SKF) can detect the hot and cold spots of the machine (bearings, belt, heat exchanger) and help
Spectral analysis can be conducted using low-frequency
vibration probe, to identify fan unbalance, bearing damage,
Resonance can occur when the dynamic natural frequency equals an integer multiple of the fan

RPM, 2 X RPM, 3 X RPM, etc. When conditions from resonance exist and there is an excitation of the fan blade, it will vibrate. If the fan is operating at a speed such that resonance occurs, the blade is continually induced to vibrate. The loads cause the blade tip to deflect since the blade root cannot. The total stress on the fan blade is now due to resonance, air load, and centrifugal loads. As the blade moves up and down, the total stress change is now much larger than if no
es 2, 3 & 4 for typical OEM blade natural frequencies

Such vibration may be difficult to monitor as the vibration direction is not perpendicular to the fan shaft but parallel, so vibration sensors may be "blind". In any case, the mechanical link between blade root or blade shaft to the fan hub shall be carefully checked (material quality, tightening, connection type) and be assessed versus any possible fatigue due to abnormal vibrations (natural or forced). As a reminder, metallic parts are preferred. If system is intended to be used at variable speeds (VFD drive or similar) then OEM shall provide detailed information regarding the blade natural frequencies (speeds to be avoided).

Further to the original commissioning and/or any modification or overhaul of the rotating parts, a vibration spectral analysis shall be conducted at site, as a “zero” reference for the mechanical behavior.
Noise Spectral analysis can track specific noise frequencies and identify troubles
hooters like fan blades, gears, plenum vibrations.
Most of ACHE’ shaft-lines are greased lubricated. To overcome the difficulty of access to the greased points, grease tubing extensions
grease lines are strongly recommended and not a common manifold one.
Oil Mist solution may solve some difficult greased cases, meeting both bearing life and
For remote greasing systems, a special care is required towards lubricant
viscosity to overcome the complete pipe/tubing
ground level to lubricated fan shaft-line.
Labyrinth seals and Bearing isolators are highly recommended (INPROSEAL VBXX, AESEAL
) versus Lip Seals which seriously damaged shaft. They improve lubrication sealing while preventing ambient moisture and dust ingress into the housing.
While individual V-belts are known to be capable of handling greater amounts of misalignment before becoming unstable, maintaining the misalignment to within 1/2-degree will maximize belt life.
The total amount of misalignment recommended
Note that synchronous drives are less tolerant of misalignment than conventional V-belt drives, and must be aligned more accurately.
When determining if a V-type drive system is aligned within these recommendations, the angular and parallel misalignment must both be measured and quantified individually, and then added together.
can then be compared to the belt manufacturer's recommendations for the particular type of drive.
is the angle at which the belt enters and exits the sprocket, and equals the sum of the parallel and angular misalignments.
Any degree of sprocket misalignment will result in some reduction of belt life

, which is not accounted for in the normal drive design procedure. Misalignment should be checked with a good straight edge or by using a laser alignment tool. The straight edge tool should be applied from driver wheel to driven wheel, and then from driven to driver so that
the total effect of parallel and angular misalignment is made visible
Laser alignment tools (laser beam) are optical devices which greatly ease the site measurements when pulleys can be accessed and which reduce the
Drive misalignment can also cause belt tracking problems. However, light flange contact by the belt is normal and won’t affect performance.

Note that depending on shaft-line dimension, the bearings type (single row taper bearings in pair, double row taper bearing) makes more difficult the complete shaft-line alignment as the mechanical installation becomes aged. Most installations for forced draft fans use a simple galvanized tube (with welded pads) as bearings carrier. When this tube is out of specs or being damaged, it often becomes impossible to line up the upper and bottom bearings without damaging the shaft. Therefore for large shaft-lines, prefer some double row spherical roller bearings.
For those drives where the center distance is greater than eight times the small sprocket diameter, belt tracking can be a problem
. In these cases, the parallel position of the two sprockets may need to be adjusted until only one flange guides the belt in the system and the belt tracks fully on all sprockets.

Regardless of the drive center distance, the optimum operation of the drive will be with the belt only contacting one flange in the system. The worst case is the contacting of flanges on opposite sides of the sprockets in the system. This traps the belt between the flanges and can force the belt into undesirable parallel misalignment.

These louvers enable to control the airflow through the tube bundle, thus modulate the heat exchanger duty based on the Air Ambient temperature (day/ night, summer/ winter). They can be manual or automatic (electric or pneumatic actuator). They are fitted at the air outlet and/or at the air intake depending on the ACHE type (FD or ID).
Typically they can suffer from an incorrect

setting (100% opening demand results in less than complete opening) or mechanical blockage (vibration failure, poor lubrication, corrosion). Thus, the recommendation when possible is to avoid these regulating devices which have a poor reliability due to infrequent use or inefficient greasing: prefer to stop/start group of air-coolers of a complete bay to adjust to the required cooling capacity and/or VFD.
Despite reduced rotation speeds, the rotor balance remains a basic topic as for any rotating machines.
Impact and deposit on blade(s) overtime can create unbalance forces which require a new rotor balancing.
Blade cracks may also lead to same mechanical trouble. On site re-balancing requires specific temporary monitoring.
In any case, balancing log shall be created.
are provided in Appendix 2. These limits are mainly defined by the effect of unbalanced rotating parts (refer to ISO 1940-1 for rigid rotor balancing and
ISO 14694 for Balance quality and Vibration levels (B-V) of Industrial Fans
), but vibrations can be also due to fittings, aerodynamics and possible interactions between plenum and fan rotor. Resonance can also take place into parts separate from blade(s).
Note that in some rare cases, duty modulation of a complete bay
by On-Off Switch management of individual fin fans can result into structural vibration.
We remind that a VFD drive means that a careful review of the
…) is required to avoid any possible excitation
for example. Be aware that the natural frequency of blade is directly linked to its
To recover normal tip clearances (wear) and suit the actual fan ring geometry (distor
Mark a line showing where to install the tip seal.
Install all pieces (except one) aligned to the upper edge drawn in step 1. For installation use self-tapping, auto perforating screws.

Adjust tip seal roller to set desired tip clearance: install it where the last section of tip seal has not been installed yet. Push fan blade with roller so as to crush the tip seal until proper depth is reached.
Install last section and push roller over last section. Remove roller!
n is often observed at the cent
High velocities will typically be located at the second half of the fan blade (outer end), becoming increasingly lower (even negative) at the centre of the fan.
Negative velocities imply a recirculation of hot air, thus a decrease in fan efficiency.
Distance from fan hub to blade tip (%)
The value of the Seal Disk (ma
de out of FRP) lies in that it "
the hot air back up into the airflow and helps to prevent air recirculation at the centre of the fan. Therefore, the Seal Disk will increase the amount of air going through the bundle.
The inlet conditions for air are particularly important for Air Cooled Heat Exchangers with a
configuration, and the same is true (but at a lesser extent) for Air Cooled Heat Exchangers with
. The installation of an Inlet Bell will limit the level of turbulence in the entrance area of the fan ring.
In the case of a straight air entry, turbulences emerge as a result of the brutality with which air enters the fan ring
). The effective surface for air entry is reduced substantially. Therefore, a smoother shape of the fan’s entrance will decrease the effect in question.
For a fan of 10’ diameter producing
O, a straight entry will approximately generate a pressure loss of 2
O. Concretely, the implication is that the useable potential of the static pressure is factually only
O that could have been achieved had the appropriate Inlet Bell been installed.
The loss incurred amounts to a 15% decrease in static pressure, which itself translates into a 7% loss in airflow through the bundle.
Most of the time, the fin fans are not secured against reverse rotation during stand.

Thus a common mean to block rotation during maintenance is to fit a pin, wood piece or chain between blades and structure. It is highly recommended to address this safety issue for future maintenance by permanent mechanical device
Note: brake may come into force with the European Machinery Directive 2006/42/EG. Regular brake system can be used or common ratchet device.
The efficiency of a fan depends on the shape of the blade (airfoil).
Nowadays, twisted blades made of FRP or
, a highly efficient fan requires a minimum of power for a maximum volume of airflow.
The power required by a fan (BHP) for a given amount of airflow (CFM) and static pressure (
P through the bundle) is inversely proportional to the
Air cooled Heat Exchanger tag E807 A3
A blade replacement test was performed at the Normandy Refinery on the unit called
blades were replaced with synthetic resin blades. Airflow measurements were performed before and after the replacement of blades.
Using more efficient fan blades generated an airflow increase of 10% while simultaneously using the same amount of electricity.

Using more efficient fan blades increases the volume of airflow going through a tube bundle (thus the duty exchanged by the cooler) using the same electrical engine for the powering of the fan (thus implying a cost reduction). A reduction in power can occasionally be observed, and in some cases it is possible to increase the speed (transmission change), and thus the airflow.
Case Study @ Provence Refinery: ALKYLATION UNIT -
New blades installation: HUDSON blades with more static efficiency
Rotation speed increase from 200 to 280 rpm: new belts and pullets
Installation of seal disk, inlet bell and tip seals.

(15% due to increase of electrical consumption and 15% due to blades efficiency, belts,

It is reported some cases of damaged synchronous belts mounted in vertical position: belts maybe machined by sprocket flange when total misalignment is excessive. Banded belts can avoid such trouble in vertical position while transmitting more torque with less slippage.
to get the proper belt tension is a

Thanks to a hydraulic actuator, the position of the motor shaft end can be adjusted to get the suitable belt tension, based on the hydraulic pressure set in the system. The belt tension is easy to control, as it only depends on the hydraulic pressure (manometer reading)
While the hydraulic tensioning system is accurate and reliable, it is quite expensive and requires reinforced structure to withstand the extra weight of the mobile platform.
Gearboxes used typically in Cooling Towers require special attention for:
lubrication (High speed & Low speed shaft-lines, heater, oil level indicator or grease lines, oil filter)
long shaft line protection (sleeve) to avoid shaft erosion/corrosion due to air turbulences or prefer full composite material for shaft when site conditions enable
torsion critical speed of the complete shaft-line
When full composite shaft is used, check against the low/high ambient temperatures the suitability of the mechanical link between coupling hubs and composite hollow shaft.
type for ACHE Forced Draft and
for Cooling Towers, it exist different possible retrofits.
Direct drive (fan directly fitted on motor shaft) is possible for reduced power rating, especially for Cooling Towers.
Electric motor can be used at constant speed, 2-speeds or continuous variable speed.
modulation of a complete bay is achieved by management of individual start-stop of each separate fin fans, it is recommended to maximize the number of starts

to prevent the spare coolers from early wear or even same level of wear: if all coolers have the same number of starts, then the complete bay can suffer from same diseases and at the same time. Stand-by management shall be carefully reviewed against maintenance policy.
Mechanical device (manual) against fan rotation during maintenance
During regular air-coolers maintenance, it is frequently reported technician injuries while belts are replaced.
To avoid such trouble, a mechanical
k any fan rotation thanks to 2 "
ted to a rotating axis. These "f
enable to lock the driven pulley, acting as a mechanical stop.
The central axis is manually operated and secured in
can be prepared in advance in workshop and only
requires 4 fixing holes in the structure for the 2 bearings
This upgrade can be implemented to most air-coolers FD type, and ensures a safe, fast and reliable means to fix any possible rotation.

General maintenance: how to cure fouling
External cleaning of tube bundle shall be carried out regularly
, especially on units considered as critical. These cleaning activities must be scheduled before the summer season (hot conditions).
Heavily fouled tube bundle due to excessive scaling.
There are several cleaning methods such as:
: this method is an easy one but it can lead to damage the fins of the tube bundle due to the energy of the high-pressure water jet.
Low pressure water sprays with detergent method
: this method is highly recommended and the most used one amongst our sites. Large amounts of water (20 m
/h) are sprayed at low-pressure levels (4 ~5 bars) in combination with a detergent.

can be considered an option in the case of specific dirt deposits (scale deposit after a bundle spraying). Although the chemical cleaning with foam method is an efficient one, it is still not widely recognized, nor used. The foam ensures that the fins are kept in contact with the active chemical element. This cleaning method requires large rinsing afterwards. In addition, careful planning should be made as to the final destination of the water used for washing (please make provisions for a neutralization process).
this method basically un-sticks the deposits that are loosely attached to the surface of the tube bundle. Although this method is very easy to use, it is only seldom used in our refineries.
Advantages of low pressure water sprays and detergent method:
Low pressure water sprays minimize the risk of damaging the fins.
The water used for washing (non-toxic and oil free) goes down the drainpipe.
Low Pressure Water Sprays + Detergent Method
Start cleaning the tubes of the lower layers
engines on (only if the engines are located above the bundle).
Proceed by cleaning the tubes of the upper layers
Finish the job by cleaning the tubes of the lower layers
Exact same procedure as in the case of the ACHE with ID.
Extra care: stop the engines and protect them, as well for the belts.
to be efficient, an average cleaning session for a dirt-ridden piece of equipment will last 4 hours per fan

. Before the upper layers of the tube bundles are cleaned, protection will be secured (this to avoid crushing the fins). This type of procedure is a standard maintained for all maintenance operations in particular on Air Cooled Heat Exchangers with induced draft.
Case Study @ Normandy refinery: Reforming unit CR6
Water wash procedure for air-side of fin fan air coolers:
Use of a detergent/surfactant mixture added to water.
For forced draft, the fan is stopped during the washing.
3 hours below the fin tubes to wash
1 hour above the fin tubes to rinse
RESULTS = airflow increased by 30% and duty increased by 10%

is to eliminate all air leaks that exist between the bundle and the plenum chamber. In other words, air seals are simply metal plates fixed by screws. As a rule of thumb, air leaks occur rarely with new equipment. On the other hand, older equipments tend to suffer from cavities in the plenum (due to corrosion) and missing air seals lost over time. Although accurately estimating the actual loss in airflow caused by missing air seals is hardly possible, replacing these air seals is an economical operation and it is certain to increase the airflow.
